column1: Antalya Province (Turkish: Antalya ili) is located on the Mediterranean coast of south-west Turkey
column2: between the Taurus Mountains and the Mediterranean Sea.

column1: Antalya Province is the centre of Turkey's tourism industry
column2: attracting 30% of foreign tourists visiting Turkey. Its capital city of the same name was the world's third most visited city by number of international arrivals in 2011
column3: displacing New York. Antalya is Turkey's biggest international sea resort. The province of Antalya corresponds to the lands of ancient Pamphylia to the east and Lycia to the west. It features a shoreline of 657 km (408 mi) with beaches
column6: including the World Heritage Site Xanthos. The provincial capital is Antalya city with a population of 1

column1: Antalya is the fastest-growing province in Turkey; with a 4.17% yearly population growth rate between years 1990–2000
column2: compared with the national rate of 1.83%. This growth is due to a fast rate of urbanization
column3: particularly driven by tourism and other service sectors on the coast.

column1: The city and thus the province are named after Attalos II
column2: king of Pergamon
column3: who founded the city in the 2nd century BC.

column1: Antalya has been settled since pre-historic times. Evidence of human habitation dating back to the early Paleolithic age (150
column3: 000) years has been discovered in the Karain cave
column4: 30 km (19 mi) of the north of Antalya city. Other finds dating back to the Mesolithic (Beldibi Cave)
column5: Neolithic (Bademağacı Höyüğü) and more recent periods show that the area has been populated by various civilizations throughout the ages.

column2: the earliest known inhabitants were a Bronze Age people called the Milyae (Milyans)
column3: who referred to the area as Milyas and spoke an Indo-European language known as Milyan. A people called the Termilae
column5: also settled and eventually dominated the coastal margins

column7: an exiled Athenian called Lykos (Latin: Lycus) became prominent in the region.  Records from the Hittite period refer to the inhabitas and the area as Lukka
column8: and document lively interactions with neighboring regions in the 2nd millennium BC. It is commonly accepted that Lukka is cognate with the later
column9: latinised exonym Lycia. The Lukka were known for their seafaring skills (including piracy) and demonstrated a fiery

column1: Before the Ancient Roman conquest Lycia was a polity with the first democratic constitution in the world
column2: which later partly inspired the American Constitution.Antalya was part of the Lydian kingdom from the 7th century BC until Lydia was defeated by the Persians during the battle of Sardis in 546 BC. The Macedonian commander Alexander the Great ended Persian rule and in around 334 BC conquered the cities of the area one by one—except for Termessos and Sillyon which managed to repulse his armies in 333 BC. After the death of Alexander in 323 BC
column3: a long battle erupted between his generals that lasted until 188 BC.

column1: The reign of the kingdom of Pergamon began with the defeat of the Seleucid army at Apamea. Shortly after this the city of Antalya was founded. When Attalos III
column2: the last king of Pergamom
column3: died in 133 BC he left his kingdom to the Ancient Romans. At this time the area is dominated by pirates based in small cities along the coast.

column1: During the mid-Byzantine era (the 5th and 6th centuries) the city of Antalya grew beyond the city walls.

From the 7th century Muslim Arabs started to be dominant in the Levant region and Antalya later played a part in the Christian Crusades against Islam. The army of Louis VII sailed from Antalya for Syria in 1148
column2: and the fleet of Richard I of England rallied here before the conquest of Cyprus. In the late 11th and early 12th Century much of the area of the modern province fell to the Turks especially the Danishmends. From 1120 to March 1207
column3: Antalya was again under the sovereignty of Byzantines.

column1: The area was conquered by the Seljuk Turks and recaptured by the Byzantines again and again from 1076 onwards as the Seljuks strove to establish a trading base on the Mediterranean. At one stage Turkish lord Kilij Arslan had a palace here. In 1220 Byzantine rule ended for the last time and the city was quickly divided into Christian and Muslim sections
column2: the Christian trading communities including Venetians and Genoese. Alanya also grew and throve during the Seljuk period.

column1: The area passed through many hands before its final occupation by the Ottoman Empire under Murad II in 1432. Antalya also was occupied by Kingdom of Cyprus between 1361 and 1373. Ottoman rule of the coast persisted until the end of the First World War
column2: when Antalya was briefly occupied by Italian troops before becoming part of the Republic of Turkey in 1921.

column1: Antalya province is situated in south-west Anatolia
column2: between the longitudes 29°20'-32°35'East and latitudes 36°07'-37°29'North. The province covers an area of 20
column3: 591 square miles. The southern border of the province is the Mediterranean Sea while the Taurus mountains draw the land border. From west to east the province is bordered by Muğla
column7: Karaman  and Mersin provinces. The land of the province is 77.8% mountainous
column8: 10.2% plain and 12% uneven. Many of the peaks of the Taurus mountains are above 500–3000 metres. The Teke peninsula (corresponds to ancient Lycia) in the west includes wide plateaus and river basins. Climate
column10: demographics and habitation patterns differ greatly between the inland mountain areas and the coastal plain.

column1: Antalya has a increasing population of internal immigrants from other cities in Turkey cause of the cities beauty.

The city of Antalya has one public university (Akdeniz University) and one private university (Antalya International University). Antalya's public education system is run by the Turkish National School Board (TNSB) (Turkish: Milli Eğitim Bakanlığı (MEB))
Antalya has a number of local media such as radio channels (such as TRT's regional radio service based in Muratpaşa) and newspapers. Kanal V
column2: the only active local television network of the province is aired nationally in Turkey by Turksat 4A satellite.

column1: The highest point of the Taurus mountains is Akdağ at an altitude of 3025 metres. Located to the northwest of the city centre and at a distance of 50 km (31 mi) is the Saklıkent ski and recreation centre on Beydağları. Here one can ski and then go down to the shore and into the sea during the months of January–April. In Saklıkent there are two teleski and ski courses along with villas and accommodation facilities available in the area. Situated on Bakırlı Hill behind Saklıkent is the Antalya National Space Observatory. It is possible to watch meteor showers and shooting stars on certain days of the year. In rivers rafting and canoeing sports and on the Taurus mountains jeep safari
column2: hunting and trekking tours are organised. Alternatively
column3: there is rock-climbing
column7: line fishing and health tourism at the thalasso and dialysis centres in Geyikbayırı. Holy tourism activities are organized in Myra and Patara where St Nicholas was born and lived. The eternal flames of Chimaera that was the inspiration for the Chimera myth is also located in Antalya. In the area of Belek
